results.title: Digital Storytelling workshop : general public express(February 2007)
results.brief_description: These eleven short stories were created as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop in February 2007. They mostly run for less than two minutes and cover diverse subject matter, including treasured family members, life changing events and vocational experiences.

results.title: My university challenge
results.creator_credit: Ray Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ray Martin and his girlfriend enrolled in a university course in Thailand to become qualified English teachers. It was here that Martin set himself a challenge that not many people had been successful at achieving.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ray Martin, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Molly's story
results.brief_description: Molly Hennessey’s children, Ann and Michael recount the life of their mother through the rich memories left with them, long after she has gone.

results.title: How should we remember Stuart?
results.creator_credit: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Speaking for her grandmother, Elizabeth, Kath Ensor remembers her grandfather, Stuart. Encompassing his time serving in the RAAF during World War II, his love for his family and his positive attitude, despite experiencing ill health.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kath Ensor, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Grass
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
Australian scientists are looking at how the use of marijuana affects the mind and body of the user. Researchers and users are shown here examining what happens to a person who is under the influence of marijuana. They investigate the claims that are often made about this drug - that marijuana leads to the use of hard drugs. Marijuana is now illegal in most countries, but the marijuana explosion of the 60s and 70s has led to a growing campaign supporting legislation.

results.title: What's visceral learning, anyway ?
results.creator_credit: Richard Handford, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
Describes the experiments of Dr Neal Miller and his team at Rockefeller University in visceral learning. Visceral learning concerns the control of the heart, the stomach and the intestines at will.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Handford, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television

results.title: 2007 Lantern Parade
results.creator_credit: Paul Bray, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Paul Bray talks about the beauty of the Lantern Parade, an event he has participated in since 2005. He considers the affect parades have on the community and the collective sense of joy and wellbeing.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Paul Bray, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI

results.title: Aurora
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
An investigation of the mystery surrounding the Aurora Borealis. An Australian physicist, Dr Robert Eather, at Boston College, Massachusetts has developed a method of filming the aurora in color.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Jones, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television

results.title: An Eye for the job
results.creator_credit: Nigel Miller, Kevin Sim and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
A documentary about the quiet revolution in the operating theatre. The surgeon has now harnessed his skills to the microscope, and operations of the most minute detail are achieved with microsurgery. Depicts five case studies - a blind painter is made to see again, a deaf grandmother can hear again, a worker’s torn off hand is restored, a man’s severed thumb is replaced by his big toe, and a young woman has her fallopian tubes untied.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nigel Miller, Kevin Sim and Yorkshire Television
